section: The Term of this Agreement shall be for a period of [* ****] years and [*****] months commencing the 1st day of September 2004 and terminating the [*****] day of [*****].
explanation: The inconsistency lies in the lack of specified end date. While the start date is clearly defined as September 1, 2004, the end date is marked with redactions, making it impossible to determine the exact duration or termination date of the agreement. This creates ambiguity as to the term and duration of the contract, rendering it difficult to enforce the contractual obligations beyond a certain point.

section: In each and every calendar year of this Agreement, CONSULTANT shall achieve a satisfactory record of play in a minimum of [* ****] professional golf association events on the SPGA and/or PGA tour (which shall include both the PGA and SPGA Tour Skins Games). If for any reason, CONSULTANT should achieve a satisfactory record of play in less than [*****] SPGA and/or PGA tour events in a calendar year, he shall repay ADAMS GOLF an amount per event for each event under [*****] achieved in the given calendar year as follows:
explanation: This section introduces a contradiction because the minimum number of tournaments required for a satisfactory record of play is redacted, creating ambiguity. The agreement stipulates a repayment obligation if the consultant fails to meet the minimum number of events, but it does not specify what the minimum is. This absence leads to a contradiction in enforcement, as it is impossible to determine when the repayment clause is triggered without knowing the minimum tournament requirement.

section: Notwithstanding any other paragraph of this Agreement, in the event that CONSULTANT dies or is unable to play tour golf at all, ADAMS GOLF may terminate this Agreement on thirty (30) days' written notice. Upon such termination, CONSULTANT and/or CONSULTANT'S estate shall be required to repay ADAMS GOLF for that period of the Agreement not performed by CONSULTANT. The repayment amount shall be calculated in the same way as repayment is calculated under paragraph 8A.
explanation: This section presents a contradiction because it demands repayment from the CONSULTANT's estate even in the event of death. Demanding repayment from the estate contradicts standard legal practices and fairness, especially considering the consultant's inability to fulfill obligations due to death. This imposes an undue burden on the consultant's heirs, as death typically terminates contractual obligations unless explicitly and reasonably stated otherwise.
